profileText: A Delegate from New Jersey; born in Riverhead, Long Island, N.Y., July 21, 1742; completed preparatory studies; moved to New Jersey; chairman of the committee of safety of Sussex County in 1774; member of the state council in 1778; served in the Revolutionary Army; chief justice of the state supreme court 1777-1787; Member of the Continental Congress in 1785 and 1786; moved to the Northwest Territory and settled in North Bend, below Cincinnati; appointed one of the three judges of the Northwest Territory in 1788 and held the position until Ohio was admitted into the Union; died in Cincinnati, Ohio, February 26, 1814; interment in Congress Green Cemetery, North Bend, Ohio.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Symmes, John Cleves. The correspondence of John Cleves Symmes, founder of the Miami Purchase, chiefly from the collection of Peter G. Thomson. Edited by Beverley W. Bond, Jr. New York: Published for the Historical and Philosophical Society of Ohio by the Macmillan Company, 1926.

------. The intimate letters of John Cleves Symmes and his family, including those of his daughter, Mrs. William Henry Harrison, wife of the ninth President of the United States. Edited by Beverley W. Bond, Jr. Cincinnati: Historical and Philosophical Society of Ohio, 1956.
------. To the Respectable Public. [Trenton: Printed by Isaac Collins, 1787].
Winfield, Charles Hardenburg. Life and Public Services of John Cleves Symmes. [Newark: N.p., 1877].

researchRecord.name: 1788-1796, 1 microfilm reel.
researchRecord.description: The microfilm reel of the papers John Cleves Symmes is from originals in the Princeton University Library (Princeton, N.J.).

researchRecord.name: 1788, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: An agreement in which John Cleves Symmes transfers two million acres of land between the Great Miami, the Little Miami, and the Ohio Rivers in Ohio to Elias Boudinot; with maps of the tract.

researchRecord.description: Other authors include John Cleves Symmes.

researchRecord.name: In the Edwin A. Ely Autograph Collection, ca. 1663-1890, 250 items.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include John Cleves Symmes.

researchRecord.name: In the Symmes Tract Records, 1787-1792, 2 volumes.
researchRecord.description: A French version of Trenton Circular, written by John Cleves Symmes, describing the Symmes Tract (also known as Miami Purchase) in Ohio's Miami River Valley, and conditions for granting lands; together with blank certificates authorizing the surveyor of the Military Range to survey lands in the third range of townships within the tract (of which only two stubs (nos. 33, 78) have been completed), printed by Francis Childs, of New York, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: In the James Taylor and Family Papers, 1783-1845, 0.5 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include John Cleves Symmes. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Draper Manuscripts: John Cleves Symmes Papers, 1791-1846, 0.8 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers of John Cleves Symmes, the elder Symmes, primarily deal with his business and land development, especially with Jonathan Dayton. Major topics discussed include the Miami Purchase and its early settlements, the government of the Northwest Territory, and military operations against the Indians. Biographical and genealogical information was extracted and summarized by Draper from the elder John Symmes's correspondence and daybook. This collection is also available as a microfilm publication.

researchRecord.name: 1803-1810, 8 items.
researchRecord.description: The letters are from John Cleves Symmes to his grandson Charles W. Short, written between 1803 and 1810.

researchRecord.name: In the John William Baldwin Papers, 1803-1915, 0.5 cubic foot.

researchRecord.name: In the Lawrence Taliaferro Papers, 1813-1868, 5 microfilm reels and 3.75 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include John Cleves Symmes.

researchRecord.name: 1786, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Cleves Symmes to an unidentified recipient written on April 15, 1786. In the letter, John Symmes writes concerning rents paid by tenants of an unidentified plantation, probably in New Jersey, that he recently sold to Gilbert Imlay, and the amount he had previously been offered for the property.
